We have had the very wealthy for a very long time and nothing we do will stop that.

What we can do is insure that workers are paid wages that allow them to live in dignity and afford their families both comfort and opportunity.
We can also eliminate the crippling poverty that millions live in and replace that poverty with, at the least, a modest and comfortable life with opportunity for even more.

As for work and money, we need to rethink these concepts, and prepare ourselves for a new world that is largely dominated by very intelligent machines.

Responding to the idea of "dependency" (from yesterday): what those who see its influence miss is what Nick Kristof described in his blog yesterday--when threatened with loss, any secure system will protect itself, especially in the face of no alternatives. The GOP constant focus on cutting benefits, not costs, causes others to fight to protect those benefits. Not as a result of dependency, but as a consequence of the stimulus of the threat. In domestic conflicts, for example, spouses often become more controlling and demanding as the relationship is threatened. Bank runs, are another example. Withdraws are prompted not by need but by fear. What is called "dependency" is often an unreasonable or extreme response to a threat, in the face of no viable alternatives, as Kristof describes.

Three words describe the idea that a first world society can have both massive inequality and small government:

Just plain stupid.

As I am supposing you are familiar with, the proponents of automation claim that automating classes of labor frees people to work in more valuable positions, both financially and intellectually.

I've seen this argument time and time again in recent discussions of robotics and automation, and thought about it myself, and no one seems to have much of any idea of what comes next.

Was this the case with previous revolutions? The printing press, steam power, electricity, the computer all changed things for the better for many, in ways that seem clear in retrospect. But it seems to me that there was much more enthusiasm about the benefits of these inventions among the intellectual classes, that there were problems waiting to be solved that were achieved through these inventions - faster dissemination of knowledge, faster and safer travel, being able to see in the dark and provide power to useful machinery that improved quality of life in noticeable ways.

On the other hand, we're now in a situation where just about everyone, even the people building and training the robots, are getting a bit nervous about the employability of humans in general. Books and steamships pretty much sold themselves, so why aren't people excited this time?

So what do 7+ billion people do when even scientists and professors are disposable?

BTW, NOT to beat a dead horse but because I think this is interesting: unless that can of mixed nuts has filberts/hazelnuts in it, it probably has no true nuts. Botanically, nuts come from a single order of trees, the beeches, which includes the oaks, birches, chestnuts and a few other families. (Walnuts and pecans are in this order but their seeds are not true nuts, but drupes or 'trymata.')

A true nut doesn't have any part of the fruit covering the hard shell. (The 'cupule' that covers many true nuts, like an acorn's cup or a chestnut's bur grows from the stem tissue, not ovary tissue. Such distinctions are why it's not obvious that one hard seed is a drupe, another from a capsule and a third a nut. And that's why the culinary definition is more useful for most of us.) For example, the fleshy covering of an almond (which is structurally identical to a plum) makes it a drupe.

The bottom line is that the only true nuts we are probably familiar with are acorns, chestnuts and filberts/hazelnuts. Beechnuts too, although for most of us it's more a brand of chewing gum than an actual thing.
Even though MOL seems to be suggesting she might be a Legume, the sad truth is that, with time, we all tun into Drupes.

Marx was not the only one to see this problem. Providing benefits to all citizens was the deal that Otto von Bismarck made to avoid revolution by the unemployed and hungry.

The problem occurs when capitalists forget that they are, in numbers, a very small minority. They depend on the rule of law to protect and generate that wealth. But the rule of law only holds sway in places where a very large part of the population feels that they benefit from the rule of law.

The alternative is the rule of war. We see revolutions happening all of the time. Our country started that way. But many have outcomes that are not so beneficial, for the wealthy or anyone at all. Adequate distribution of wealth is necessary for the existence of wealth.

It might also help to un-couple healthcare from employment. If everyone had healthcare (i.e. single payer) that was paid through taxes, employers wouldn't have to use that as a lever to employ, or not employ, individuals. In addition, huge corporations like Walmart might have to start paying a decent wage instead of depending on the government to subsidize the poor incomes of it's employees with food stamps and Medicaid.

In my experience, as a no longer young former big law worker with a PhD in psychology, the working hours issue is not just economic.

The management works long hours, often longer than employees who are working 60 hours. The way they became managers was by being an employee who worked extra time to network with the management and who learned what tasks managers perform. They got picked out as high potential employees, and by staying longer than others and doing additional work running the company as well as producing for the company, they became managers. There is somewhat of a meritocracy here.

The problem, though, is that the managers, who work long hours, see working long hours as normal. It's what they did to get where they are, and it's what they continue to do as managers.

In addition to seeing it as normal, they also know that they have sacrificed time with family, friends, leisure, to work long hours to become managers. Seeing others work long hours validates their choice. Seeing others happily going home after 40 hours makes them think that maybe they made the wrong choice in working such long hours if most others would be happier working fewer.

This confusion is known as cognitive dissonance, and people try to end this uncomfortable state in whatever way they are able. Managers can't make employees unhappy with working 40 hours. But managers can make people work long hours, as they did, to comfort themselves with the belief that long hours are normal.

A "standard 40 hour work week." What person who wants to build a future work only five days a week and 40 hours a week?
Do you think Paul Krugman works only 40 hours a week? Or Bill Gates, or Warren Buffet, of the individual who owns the donut shop, or the owner of the McDonald's you ate at, or the owner of a landscaping/gardening business?

I grew up on a farm. You began work as soon as it was light outside and came in when it was dark. You worked six days a week. Your personal life came from the fact you were working with your family.

Our modern society has created this fantasy of a five-day, 40 hour work week that supports provides enough income to pay a mortgage, own two cars, pay for kids and their education, pays for health care, pays for vacations and X mas, and pays for retirment.

People with common sense recognize this as a fallacy and work six or seven day weeks 50-60 hours a week if not more. This makes them much wealthier than the people who stopped at 5 days and forty hours. The hard workers get attacked by demagogues for being "rich" as if they term means they didn't earn their money through hard work.

About 35% of Americans today are plain lazy and believe they have a right to the same lifestyle as hard working Americans. Political demagogues perpetuate this lunacy to the detriment of the nation.

One thing that I think has not been discussed recently on top of these issues is the fact that we currently have underemployment and overemployment. The majority of professionals work closer to 50-60 hours a week compared to the standard 40. They also get paid the same amount since they are on salary. This effectively lowers the costs of a company by reducing the number of people they would have to give benefits. It also has dramatic implications in terms of mental health of the work force. Both sides are unhappy. One side struggles to make ends meet and the other struggles to have a personal life. This factor probably has to do with the decreased power of labor in bargaining, which also contributes to massive pay offs to the higher ups. It seems like it would solve a lot of problems if we just went back to working a standard amount of time in comparison to regularly working 10 hr days as professionals.

I am young though. So I am kind of just speculating into what it was like in previous times for work hours, but it seems to make common sense to solve a problem of under and over employment.

"A similar lesson can be learned from our own experience here in the US. Out of a revolutionary war, we crafted a Constitution and, shortly thereafter, a Bill of Rights"

Yes. If we look to our experience for application to Egypt, remember that after our Revolution we crafted a government that did not work.

Our Constitution was our second effort, after ten years of failure of our first effort. Even then, it did not pass. We had to add the Bill of Rights with ten amendments just to get the thing adopted.

Applying our scale, Egypt would blunder along without a workable government until 2022, and the draft Constitution proposed in 2022 would be wrong and would not pass until extensively amended to protect rights.

I think (hope) Egypt will do much better than that.

It was hard for us. It will be hard for them.
The abuses you call overemployment deserve a lot more attention.  That is a valuable idea.

To fireweed--this is happening right now to an adoptive couple in Utah who believed their adoption was final.  The birthfather's rights were terminated because the adoption agency had been unable, or so they said, to contact him; but in fact he was married to the birthmother, serving in the Armed Forces, and supporting the birthmother.  He fully expected to support his child but the birthmother left him and placed their baby for adoption without letting him know.  When he returned he searched for months (the adoption agency refused to give him any information), found the child, and started legal proceedings to get custody.  The adoptive couple has been ordered to return her to her father but are trying to challenge that ruling.

One problem with your 'solution' Karen.  Very few babies are "unwanted." Many adult adoptees "wish" that infertile couples would accept their infertility and stop creating a demand for infants.  The majority of children given up for adoption belong with their mothers, as nature intended.

Yelena - That the family the hypothetical kidnapped child has been living with was not a party to the kidnapping is a moot point. It's your hypothetical kid, unjustly taken from you and being cared for by somebody else.

Me? I'd move heaven and earth to get my kid back ASAP. A kid deserves to grow up in their original family if it is possible.

As sad as it is for the Carr's and Geovany, I can only commend Guatemala for their new-found focus on disrupting child trafficking.

Some of the blame for Guatemala's new reticence has to be laid at the US's doorstep. In one of the most well-known cases, that of Karen Abigael, a little girl was grabbed from her own front yard in Guatemala. The mother searched for years, finally able to track her child to the US. Her child has been identified and is living in Missouri. International courts have ordered her returned. The response of the US? We're not going to help you.

Although it seems unfair to the Carr's, and heartbreaking for Geovanny, Guatemala slowing down adoptions will serve to make child-trafficking much less lucrative, which is only for the good, for Geovanny included.

Jules--that is a terrible story about the Pakistani girl who was trafficked.  But when the adoption was initially prevented because of that, it's not like she was returned to her parents.  It's unclear if she was stolen; they may have wanted her to be adopted.  But what actually happened was that she languished in an Islamabad orphanage for two years and when the adoptive mom found her there the child was very ill.  I don't think it's fair to say that the adoptive mom didn't care that she was trafficked, though.  But at that point when no one knows where she belongs and the choice is permanent institutionalization or trying to make the adoption happen, well, that's a bad situation but the better choice does seem clear.  It's sad that these things happen and it's something that we as a society need to figure out how to fix.

My heart aches for this little boy and the family involved. We brought home our third and fourth children from Ethiopia this spring "only" seventeen months after they had entered the orphanage system and it was a gutwrenching process. I'm thankful that we'd always planned on stopping at four children, because I can't imagine going through that journey again.
I am very grateful that the U.S. Embassy and the Ethiopian government are now scrutinizing adoptions more carefully and causing changes to be put in place that will better assure everyone involved that the adoptions are ethical and the result of children truly needing new families. However, I also remember the rooms and rooms of children we saw at orphanages who needed families and am very saddened to think of them languishing there while governments fail to make it a priority to place them in real homes.

Millions? There are not millions of children available for adoption.
It is not as easy as you think to adopt from the county and state agencies.
I waited for three years in Minnesota and I was never paired with a child because there was not a single child available in all that time that came in a sibling group of less than three. Not only that, not one of the sibling groups available were an option for a single parent because of the extent of their educational, medical and therapeutic needs. They all, without exception, needed a full-time stay at home parent to address all of their appointments and behaviors at school.
